history.content:
BEFORE THE SEMESTER:

Go onto imt-decal.org and watch Suraj's video lectures. Do the homeworks and midterm/final from IMT. Preview the CS70 notes during break. Actually, you can go ahead and attempt to self-learn the material over break. There's ~15 notes and ~30 days in the break, so spend the first half of the break on IMT and the second half on reading the CS70 notes. During the break, the new semester's website may be under construction so use eecs70.org/fa19 (or su19, sp19, whatever floats your boat).

-----

Seconding the IMT decal! The book is very accessible and more fun to read than the scary LaTeX course notes imo and Suraj is great at explaining things, so it's a good place to start. I wouldn't stress yourself out over break too much, but definitely previewing the material is the way to go.

-----

Suraj is indeed amazing.

DURING THE SEMESTER:

go to office hours a lot! The profs and TAs really want you to succeed! Stay on top of the material. Go to live lecture. Participate on Piazza! If you know something and are confident, answer another student's question! If you're unsure about anything, anything at all, dumb question whatever, ask it on Piazza or OH!

I'm a dumb bear and this strategy works lol. I tend to need a lot of time to grasp material so the head start during summer/winter break really helps. Good luck!

-----

The most helpful things for me were consistently going to office hours and solidifying my own understanding of the material by answering piazza questions :)) A lot of people recommend reading the notes before lecture so that lecture is more of a review for you-- I personally found the other way around to be much more helpful, stuff was more intuitive during lecture and then I'd go over the notes afterwards to grasp all the smaller details (I took it over the summer and the lecturers were pretty good so YMMV) but that's just me, you have to figure out what strategy works for you. The probability section was quite difficult for me because I didn't know any probability beforehand so I'd suggest watching some videos or something that build intuition for how the continuous probability concepts relate to each other, prior to getting to that unit in class. Weird flex but I didn't have any relevant experience at all (and was super scared because last spring I screwed up math 1b and was thinking how in the world I would do cs70 math if math1b was decently hard to me) but after living in office hours and dedicating a lot of time to the class I made an A :)) you can do it!! 

$${\color{Orange}{go}} {\color{Blue}{ \ bears}} $$

Really stressed out about taking this class next semester and was wondering if anyone had tips to do well in 70. I don't have any discrete/competition math experience -- am I screwed?? I've decided to make it my only technical class next semester, so that way I can dedicate my entire sem to just CS70 in hopes of getting a B+.   

Any advice on doing well would be very appreciated. thank you.  -- a very stressed bear
history.subject: Tips for succeeding in CS70?
